header.title: The Scroll of Set (Issue Number 17, Volume II-5, January 1977)
header.category: Esotericism, Occultism, Setianism, Left Hand Path

central_thesis: The Scroll of Set, Issue 17, outlines the foundational philosophy of the Temple of Set, emphasizing the nature of Set as a non-supernatural, highly evolved Intelligence guiding individual Setian self-evolution (Setamorphosis) towards a 'more than human level' (Xeper). It also establishes core organizational principles, including the importance of tolerance within the occult community and practical guidelines for members interacting with non-members and the media.

structure_content.summary: This article redefines 'god' in the Setian context, portraying Set not as a supernatural deity but as a non-terrestrial, supremely evolved Intelligence. It describes the 'Elect of Set' as those who can perceive and evolve beyond human limitations through a 'touching' of the mind by Set, leading to 'Setamorphosis'. This process is individualistic, aiming for a 'more than human level' of mind and will, with Set acting as a guide rather than a controller. The piece concludes with a poetic statement from Set emphasizing self-reliance and the power of the Setian's own sight and strength derived from Set.

This article advocates for tolerance within and outside the Temple of Set. It reaffirms the Temple's policy against seeking converts, stating that membership is only for those who actively seek it. It argues that Setians should tolerate those with differing beliefs as long as they pose no threat, emphasizing that true strength allows for others' weaknesses to become self-evident. Intolerance, ridicule, and condemnation are framed as destructive poisons, hindering both the object and the practitioner. The author encourages mutual respect over judgment, particularly for those pursuing different but sincerely held paths.

This section provides practical guidelines for Setians on how to manage interactions with non-members and the news media. It stresses that the Temple is not mass-oriented and publicity is a low priority. Members are instructed to use provided cardstock pamphlets for initial inquiries and to direct media requests to the Priesthood. The article advises against initiating contact with the media and emphasizes that Setian time and energy are too valuable for anything not leading to Xeper, including entertaining those only mildly curious. It also discusses the importance of maintaining the Temple's ethics and dignity in all public interactions.

key_concepts.definition: A non-terrestrial Intelligence, supremely evolved beyond human comprehension, finite in its existence but with unparalleled power and will. It is not a supernatural deity in the traditional sense, but a real entity perceived as a true god by evolved intellects.

Individuals gifted with the ability to evolve their will, mind, and intelligence beyond human capacities. They possess a 'non-physical sight' (of the mind/intelligence) that allows for recognition and 'knowing' when confronted with Set.

The process by which Set enables individuals to evolve their minds and wills to a 'more than human level'. This involves a 'touching' of the mind by Set, altering its capacity without controlling or manipulating the individual's will. It leads to Setians becoming collective yet individual guardians of a highly evolved race.

The ultimate goal and process of Setian individual evolution and becoming. It represents the transformation and self-creation of the individual, for which all Setian time and energy are considered valuable and scarce commodities. (Implied from context, meaning 'I have come into being' or 'I have transformed myself' in ancient Egyptian).
A title for Set, explicitly stated in the text not to be a dishonor, affirming the Setian acceptance of this traditional nomenclature in a non-pejorative sense.

Refers to traditional or mainstream spiritual and religious dogmas, often contrasted with the Left Hand Path. The text suggests that while these systems may contain 'rotten apples,' Setians should not condemn the entire population based on the actions of a few, advocating for tolerance.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined is one of individual, internal transformation and self-evolution ('Setamorphosis' leading to 'Xeper') rather than a prescriptive ritual magic manual. The core operative principle is the cultivation of one's 'will, mind, intelligence' through a 'touching' by Set, leading to a 'more than human level'. Set acts as a guide, but the individual must actively 'seek, to will... to Become.' This emphasizes self-reliance and internal work. Additionally, a practical system for external interaction is provided, dictating how members should engage with non-members and the media through controlled information dissemination and referral to leadership, ensuring the Temple's dignity and focus on its internal objectives are maintained.
tools: The primary internal tool is the individual's 'will, mind, intelligence' and their developed 'non-physical sight'. Externally, 'cardstock pamphlets' are specified for initial information dissemination to non-members, and 'follow-up informational sheets' for more serious inquiries. The 'great pentagram' serves as a symbolic tool for channeling Set's power.
rituals: The text alludes to 'the magic of my great pentagram' in Set's voice, suggesting that symbolic or energetic engagements are part of the Setian path, though no specific ritual mechanics or practices are detailed. The statement 'The Setian need conjure neither curse nor kindness from me' implies a direct, non-ritualistic connection to Set's power, or that traditional conjuration is unnecessary as Set's presence is inherent to the Setian's power.

relevant_quotes.text: He is not a supernatural deity of the kind expounded in traditional religious dogma, but rather a non-terrestrial Intelligence developed to a scope and capability non-intuitive to the human mind at its present level of evolution. He is finite, yet his power and will are such that no creature of the universe may stand against them.

What is its nature? Simply stated, it is a 'touching' of the mind by the Intelligence which is Set, an altering of the mind to a capacity which we would not normally possess in the course of uninterfered-with human evolution. It is not a control or manipulation of the will, but rather a process by which the Dark Prince has enabled us to evolve our minds, our Wills: to bring about and achieve Setamorphosis each on his own and in so doing become collectively, but still individually, the guardians, guides and foundation of a race whose minds and wills are developed to a more than human level.

Set is quite real, with a power and will on such a scale and level of evolution that he is correctly perceived as a true god, past understanding or recognition by a non-evolved human intellect. He has given his Elect the same abilities, albeit in a still-undeveloped stage, but capable of evolving to the same heights if we will to do so. He will not accomplish it for us; this we must do individually, but he is ever near to guide, to teach, to 'touch' our minds. We have but to seek, to will ... to Become.

Now let the Setian shun all recitation, for the text of another is an affront to the Self. Speak rather to me as to a friend, gently and without fear, and I shall hear as a friend. Do not bend your knee nor drop your eye, for such things were not done in my house at PaMat-Et.

The Setian need conjure neither curse nor kindness from me, for by the magic of my great pentagram I shall see with his eyes. And then the strength that is mine shall be the strength of the Setian, and against the Will of Set no creature may stand. And I think not of those who think not of me.

The policy of the Temple to not seek converts is a result of our firm philosophy that only someone who seeks information and membership is worthy of it. To do otherwise is to force our way of life on others. It would be hypocritical and unproductive to do otherwise.

I believe that it is necessary to tolerate those who disagree with us as long as they do not threaten our existence or well-being. If we are truly strong and Elect, we need not point out the weaknesses of others; they soon will be self-evident.

Intolerance, which is the undeserved ridicule, condemnation, or action against others, is destructive not only of the object, but also of the practitioner. It is a poison that slowly erodes, never seen but always present. It is the specter of negativism; and once the infection strikes, it is difficult to overcome.
Setian time and energy are commodities far too valuable and scarce to be expended on anything which does not lead to Xeper.

If a person has read the pamphlet and is not willing to spend a buck to learn more, then that person couldn't be too interested in the Temple. As we said before, a Setian's time is too valuable to be spent entertaining someone who is not even interested a dollar's worth in what you are saying.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant to the study of modern Western Esotericism, particularly the Left Hand Path and the foundational period of the Temple of Set (ToS). Published early in the ToS's history, it articulates key philosophical distinctions from traditional occultism, such as the non-supernatural nature of Set and the emphasis on individual 'Setamorphosis' towards self-deification (Xeper). This positions the ToS as a uniquely intellectual and psychologically oriented esoteric order, diverging from devotional or purely ceremonial magic. The text's strong stance on tolerance and public relations guidance reflects a pragmatic approach to operating an esoteric group in a broader society, contrasting with more secretive or confrontational occult movements. It signifies a mature self-awareness regarding public perception and internal group cohesion.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of existing Initiates of the Temple of Set, especially those at the III° and IV° levels, as indicated by the authors' degrees and the internal nature of the publication. It serves to reinforce core doctrines, provide ethical guidelines, and offer practical instructions for organizational conduct (e.g., handling media, maintaining discretion). A secondary audience includes potential initiates or those expressing genuine curiosity, for whom the 'cardstock pamphlets' are intended as an initial, controlled introduction to the Temple's philosophy.
